subject: openpower-debug-collector: Change to accept error log id as integer
commitMessage:
openpower-debug-collector: Change to accept error log id as integer

The input error log id is needs to be a 32 bit number and
There will be an error logged if the error log id does
not fit into that specification and dump will be generated
with filling 0s in the place for error log id in the dump header.

Tested:
   Tested with both valid and invalid inputs as
   error log id.

Results:
With invalid inputs

~# busctl --verbose call org.open_power.Dump.Manager /org/openpower/dump xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Create CreateDump a{ss} 0
Call failed: Invalid arguments 'a{ss}' to call xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Create.CreateDump(), expecting 'a{sv}'.

~# busctl --verbose call org.open_power.Dump.Manager /org/openpower/dump xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Create CreateDump a{sv} 0
Call failed: Invalid argument was given.
Jul 26 11:48:51 openpower-dump-manager[1741]: Required argument, dump type is not passed
Jul 26 11:48:51 openpower-dump-manager[1741]: Invalid argument was given.

~# busctl --verbose call org.open_power.Dump.Manager /org/openpower/dump xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Create CreateDump a{sv} 1  "com.ibm.Dump.Create.CreateParameters.DumpType" s "com.ibm.Dump.Create.DumpType.Hostboot"
Call failed: Invalid argument was given.
Jul 26 11:51:33 openpower-dump-manager[1741]: Required argument, error log id is not passed
Jul 26 11:51:33 openpower-dump-manager[1741]: Invalid argument was given.

~# busctl --verbose call org.open_power.Dump.Manager /org/openpower/dump xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Create CreateDump a{sv} 2  "com.ibm.Dump.Create.CreateParameters.DumpType" s "com.ibm.Dump.Create.DumpType.Hostboot" s "com.ibm.Dump.Create.CreateParameters.ErrorLogId" "DEADBEEF"
Failed to create bus message: Invalid argument

Good Path:
MESSAGE "o" {
        OBJECT_PATH "/xyz/openbmc_project/dump/hostboot/entry/35";
};
Header:
00000130  31 33 39 46 32 42 30 00  de ad be ef 00 00 00 00  |139F2B0.........|

Signed-off-by: Dhruvaraj Subhashchandran <dhruvaraj@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I4fad73a99e828f6ae98a2acbf772e52c55e54241

Patch Set 16:

Note: The respective dbus interface documentation should be updated with all required information (about expecting decimal format in error log id) before merging this patch.

I think the better solution will be "Use uint32_t instead string type for error log id in dbus interface and convert into hex as per backend expectation so that no need any restriction (only decimal) to a consumer of this dbus interface.

Giving +1 (ok to pull into downstream - no functional blocker) because this patch needs to pull in downstream to unblock testing. - Not sure why we are tie-up with the vendor-specific downstream process (need +1 from the upstream patch to pull in downstream) into the upstream process- Need to discuss

This is a wrong statement from the vendor perspective - some misunderstanding on this process. 
Apologies for making the wrong process-oriented comment.

typo
Done
Add test details
will add in the pull request

d-bus documentation just say's "The id of the log associated with action which triggered the
dump". Not specifying data length or format. I think we should add documentation update in d-bus documentaion to avoid confusion from user. Add respective check here.  

Avoid hard coding instead that use meaningful constexpr from readability.

On DBus side there wont be a restriction, restriction is only on this specific implementation side.

will change to constexpr

How the user know , what format should supported . Not sure , it is good idea to ask user look the code and use the d-bus accordingly. Need documentation on this some common place . i felt dbus documenation may be better. Incase you think if it is implemention specific you need to update read document about the ID exepection specific to phosphor-debug collector.
Looks like user implemetaion code not in sync that is why this problem triggerd now.
Readme is good place to add the documentation, will update that
Why this check is added here? can you add comments.
This is for removing any leading hex identifier

Are you assuming 0x is alway's going to be first , if that is the case you need to change logic in line 391. Otherwise this logic is broken incase 0x is come in between.

I will continue review after seeing the documentation update or adding proper commnet here.
0x always comes in the first as hex indicator
Based on the discussion with Ben T and Dhruv, this fix is not going to fix the actual issue.
Could be more than 8 characters it is a decimal representation - will throw if it does not fit into a long.
ya I will update this comment for clarity

I think you are refering create d-bus interface below parameter.
 - name: 'ErrorLogId'
     description: >
              The id of the log associated with action which triggered the  dump.
Since this is com/bm interface , can we enforce user to pass hexa decimal string directly based on IBM spec requirement. That will help to avoid this conversion. 

Also please include Readme or d-b us documentation update.

that needs xyz.openbmc change to change the variables in the dictionary and the decision was to accept all as list of strings

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Dump/Create.interface.yaml#L19

Since this is [String, String] dictionary for IBM implementation you can enfornse 0xNNNNNNNN format right? that is what i am refering here.you can update com/ibm implmentationreadme according to that.

this is a discussed solution, and the error log id is not internally a string but a number, and the 0xNN.. string is needed only for adding to header. Ideally the conversion should done while adding to the header but that is done in this layer because there is no way to log errors while creating dump headers.
Need Readme update for , which includes the valid format details.
error log id
Done
and continue creating dump?
yes
need update here.

include errno
Done
Address previous patcset comments "Include verification results."
Done
ERROR LOG ID : 32 bit number in hex format?
not in hex format
Do you mean "convert"???
correct , more readble.
Done
Tested: ? https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing
changing to tested

Please add some data about valid and invalid format because it will be useful to get to know what are test cases you are covered and anything that needs to consider from the reviewer's point of view.

I think the Reviewers won't aware that, what are values we covered in TCs if we just mentioning tested with valid and invalid error log id.
In code, you are converting into hex by default so please add that point here i.e consumer of this interface must use non-hex value.
Generally if explicitly not saying hex or oct or bin it should be decimal
Still you can mention like doing hex conversion as per your implementation expectation.
It is general assumption when we say number it is in base10.
anyway I am planning to push a commit in create to accept number here instead of string to avoid any further confusions
What is blocking to add this as part of this commit?
that change is in phosphor-dbus-interfaces
Changing the API from number to string will break all code that has been written to the existing API definition.
Changing from string to number I mean.
no will not do in a day.. only if that commit get approved..
Why not this line can not go into above try {} and catch {} block ? since you are decoding given error log id in that block ?
the idea is if nothing is provided, that is not a valid command so throw error. but if an invalid number is passed create the dump with an error log

> the idea is if nothing is provided

Since your `params` is std::map so, you can use `find()` instead of `at()` to make sure whether the error log id is given or not and add log with an appropriate message.

> if an invalid number is passed

Right, you will get an exception and you can catch that in your above try block 
but, if you used `at()` then you cannot differentiate the error because `at()` and `stol()` will throw same exception `std::out_of_range` for different reason. 

JS: It's up to you - I am trying to avoid one more try{} and catch{} for error log  id process.
Done

- errno will set for std:stol() ? I am not seeing any document on this (https://www.cplusplus.com/reference/string/stol/) can you point me the reference which one you are looking ?
- you can use errno directly ? why one more variable here ?
asked add  strerror(errno) , missed to add strerror previous comment.

it throws out of range with setting the error no.
since log() can have system calls to be safe assigning to a variable

> it throws out of range with setting the error no

ah sorry, I missed the underlying c function `std::strtol` call from c++ function call `stol()`

and looks I am referring old document instead looking latest (https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/stol) - sorry for the confusions.

> since log() can have system calls to be safe assigning to a variable

ok,
Can you add ERRMSG as well i.e strerror(errno) ?
this should be fine.. already the inputs are documented

Yeah, it is well documented but, we can look at trace itself instead of looking at document based on the error code.

JS: It's up to you to include.
printing errno  is cleaner way, and followed by BMC coding .
errno is already there right?

I am not seeing any documentation on this i.e you are converting into hex irrespective of the given value is in hex format or not.

is anywhere you mentioned like error log id must be non-hex format? if so, please point me.
I am not explicitly specifying hex, then the general assumption it should be a decimal number.
I am not sure everyone knows the assumption what you are making here and it will be always good if we documented those assumption to avoid others confusion.
It is very generic that if you dont mention it a decimal number and should explicitly mention if it is not base10
Documentation is alway's better for future refernce.
Yes here the problem is, explicitly stating a number should be decimal, do we really need to do that?

What happens if I give error id like below

1234 vs 0x4D2

if someone pass 0x4D2 it will fail saying invalid number 
and if someone pass 400 assuming hex.. it get converted to hex again.. I agree to all those but nobody suppose to pass hex unless explicitly mentioned.. otherwise it is a string where you can pass binary, octal or hex, but that is not correct as long as explicitly mentioning binary. octal or hex,

> it is a string where you can pass binary, octal or hex, 

then why you are saying failing "if someone pass 0x4D2 and it will fail saying invalid number"

As you said, the type is a string and I can pass 1234 or 0x4D2 or 10011010010 or 2322, all represent the same error log id "1234" - this is where getting confusion. 

are you saying pass decimal value in error log id field but, its data type is a string ?
yes a decimal value is expected as long as it is not explicitly mentioned any other format
and if at all someone want to pass a hex number like 4D2 they have to pass 4D2h and that will be taken as 4D2 itself

> 4D2h 
?? is it acceptable - I know we can use Ox4D2 - tried in some test code with 4D2h but, no luck - can you point me some reference on this? is it portable?

and also it contradicts previous your comments (below)

>if someone pass 0x4D2 it will fail saying invalid number vs if at all someone want to pass a hex number like 4D2 they have to pass 4D2h

I last totally, what are all formats you will accept and not  - since you are using string type so, as a consumer of this dbus interface, I have a free hand to pass anything since no documentation about which format I need to send. 

and also, You are not returning any exception on the invalid data if the dbus interface consumer giving the wrong format, just proceeding, then How this dbus interface consumer will get to know that passing invalid format? - What is the intention to pass error log id by a consumer? The consumer no need to bother while proceeding with "0" error log id? is conveyed anywhere to the consumer (again I am talking about documentation)?

I am fine if you are throwing an error on this invalid format which you are not expecting - please add those TCs details in the commit message.

Still, I am preferring documentation but, I will agree with your point if you are using type as integer (or relevant data type in dbus interface) but, for string type, I don't think we can consider the assumption (I am not saying consider assumption while talking about interface which is going to use by a consumer - interface must be well documented with require info which is needed to considered by a consumer).
I will be agreeing with your arguments if the number accepted was any other that decimal which usually doesn't need a special mention.
Updated the commit.. only decimal is accepted, so no confusion

- Can you make each point a bullet format?
- following one confusing?
  - "error log id is a 32bit decimal number converted to string" - who needs to do this conversion? consumer of this interface?
  - "An error will be logged and dump will be collected with error log id as 0 if an invalid number is passed." - Do we need to add a note on this? like, consumers of this interface should take the responsibility of passing the expected format else we will lose the error log id in the dump header, right?

Do you need to update document in respective dbus interfaces as well (if this is a permanent fix) - I think everybody will look at dbus interface documentation instead implemented daemon
OR 
This is just a workaround and later you will change the signature for error log id in dbus interfaces? - if it is a workaround please mention that in the commit message and in code as well.
whitespace

changing to bullet

An error will be logged and dump will be collected with error log id as 0, 
    if an invalid number is passed
Done
start using libfmt

not fit into that specification and dump will be generated
with filling 0s in the place for error log id in the dump header.
say's exception , is it typo?

ya.. no exception only logging error, will change the comment

This is the max supported error log id, max 32bit number
